content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays four separate pieces of tissue. Based on their ovoid shape, dense cellularity (dark purple staining), and surrounding adipose tissue, they are consistent with lymph nodes. The primary task is to systematically examine each of these nodes for the presence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the third lymph node from the top (the one on the lower left). I have zoomed into the peripheral/subcapsular region. This area is critically important to inspect because metastatic cells traveling through lymphatic channels typically first lodge in the subcapsular sinus. At low power, this specific area may have appeared more eosinophilic or architecturally different from the surrounding lymphoid tissue, warranting a closer look for potential tumor deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, located in the top-left lymph node, because it represents one of the most prominent pale, eosinophilic, and architecturally disrupted regions seen on low power. These features are classic red flags for metastatic carcinoma replacing the normal lymph node parenchyma. The purpose of zooming in is to examine the cytology of the cells in this area at high magnification to confirm whether they are malignant epithelial cells, which would make this a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node to screen for metastasis. The zoom is on the fourth lymph node (bottom right). The specific area targeted is the subcapsular region. This is a critical area to examine as it is the most common site for initial metastatic deposits to lodge after arriving via afferent lymphatics. At low power, this region might have appeared slightly paler or architecturally different from the normal lymphoid tissue, raising suspicion for tumor infiltration. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area, located on the periphery of the first (top) lymph node, because it appears slightly detached and irregular on the low-power view. When searching for metastasis, it is crucial to meticulously examine the capsule and the surrounding perinodal soft tissue. Tumor cells often first arrive in the subcapsular sinus and can subsequently break through the capsule, a feature known as extranodal extension (ENE). This fragmented-looking area outside the main lymphoid aggregate is highly suspicious for either a tumor deposit or ENE, and requires high-magnification assessment. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the lymph node capsule and surrounding perinodal adipose tissue at the bottom. Within the lymph node parenchyma, there are nests and clusters of large, atypical cells with pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. These features are characteristic of malignant glandular epithelium. These tumor cell nests are infiltrating the lymphoid tissue. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the normal, small, dark lymphocytes being extensively infiltrated and replaced by large, cohesive clusters of malignant cells. These tumor cells have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large irregular nuclei with vesicular chromatin, and prominent nucleoli. They are forming poorly-defined glandular structures. There are also central areas of 'dirty' necrosis (the bright pink, acellular material). My impression is unequivocal: this is metastatic adenocarcinoma within the lymph node. This confirms the node is positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense infiltrate of malignant cells, which have replaced the normal lymphoid tissue. These cells are arranged in irregular nests and cords, separated by thin fibrous septa. The tumor cells are large and pleomorphic, with hyperchromatic (darkly stained), irregular nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm. The overall morphology is that of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, clearly showing metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a cluster of malignant cells in the soft tissue, adjacent to a large, thick-walled blood vessel. The malignant cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei and are arranged in poorly formed nests, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. They are infiltrating a desmoplastic stroma. My impression is that this represents extranodal extension of metastatic carcinoma. The tumor has breached the lymph node capsule and is invading the surrounding perinodal soft tissue. This is a critical finding that upstages the disease and has significant prognostic implications.
